column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.StanzaNER|value
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Relationships|Relationship|BT_webanno.custom.StanzaNER
#Text=A 12th century Hindu sculpture stolen from Nepal in 1982 and returned from a Berlin museum in 2000 .
#Text=Dhulikhel , Nepal is on the ancient trade route between central Nepal and Tibet , at a natural stopping point 35 km east of Kathmandu .
#Text=Five centuries of commerce brought prosperity and prosperity encouraged a flowering of both secular and religious art .
#Text=The town ’ s old centre contains numerous temples which contain high quality pieces of Hindu sacred art .

#Text=One such piece is a remarkably fine Uma Maheshwar ( also Uma Maheshvara ) themed stone carving which shows Shiva ( Maheshvara ) reclining with Parvati ( Uma ) surrounded by deities and animals on Mount Kailas .
#Text=The 62 cm piece is made of gray limestone and is an estimated 800 years old .
#Text=It was stolen from a shrine in the Wotol area of Dhulikhel in 1982 .
#Text=Uma Maheshwar images appear to be popular among international art collectors .

#Text=Following the theft , residents of Wotol continued to place flowers and offerings on the rounded rock in the empty neighbourhood shrine where the statue had been , praying for the Uma Maheshwar ’ s return .
#Text=The Uma Maheshwar surfaced in 1995 in the inventory of a German art dealer in Wiesbaden .
#Text=It was purchased by the Museum für Indische Kunst in Berlin for $ 50,000 USD .
#Text=Sometime after this purchase , it came to the attention of both Lain S Bangdel and Jürgen Schick that the Uma Maheshwar was in Berlin .
#Text=Since the 1980s , Bangdel and Schick had been documenting and photographing the sacred art of the Kathmandu Valley and , in particular , had been recording antiquities theft from the region .
#Text=Independently , both had taken photos of the Uma Maheshwar in situ prior to its theft in 1982 which they transmitted to the Museum für Indische Kunst .
#Text=This piece was certainly in Nepal long after 1956 when the Ancient Monuments Preservation Act came into effect .

#Text=Article 12 of the Act criminalises theft from ancient monuments and Article 13 restricts the export of cultural objects without prior Government approval , meaning an official permit issued by the Department of Archaeology .
#Text=Nepal does not issue such permits for ancient pieces destined for the private market .

#Text=The former Director General of the Department of Archaeology in Kathmandu , Riddi Pradhan , has said “ There is no doubt about it , nearly every one of our statues left the country as contraband , against our laws .
#Text=They are stolen goods , and hence remain the property of Nepal , owned by the country and the communities where they were originally situated ” .
#Text=No export permit was issued for the Uma Maheshwar .
#Text=The Museum für Indische Kunst , which maintains that it was unaware that the Uma Maheshwar was stolen , was receptive to Nepal ’ s claim for the piece .
#Text=The museum ’ s director , Mariane Yaldiz stated that “ once [ we ] knew the image was stolen we did not hesitate in deciding to return the relief to Nepal…it was the only correct decision ” .
#Text=The Uma Maheshwar was formally returned to Nepal on 28 August 2000 .
#Text=When asked around that time about the dealer that sold the piece to the Museum für Indische Kunst , Yaldiz reportedly said that they had disappeared .
#Text=The Uma Maheshwar was not returned to Dhulikhel out of security fears as several stolen , recovered , and reinstalled sculptures had been stolen again around the time of the return .
#Text=Instead the piece was initially displayed in the Patan Museum , 28 km from Dhulikhel , with eventual return to Dhulikhel considered a possibility .
#Text=At the time of writing , the piece remains in the Patan Museum as Object SS 808 ( Patan Museum nd ) .
#Text=[ Image via The Patan Museum ]
